title: Case 20: Tinnitus and Hyponatremia
chief_complaint: I have a ringing in my right ear that started as crickets and now sounds like a waterfall.

problem_summary.course: Sudden onset while bending over; tinnitus character changed over time.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Significant anxiety, recent hospitalization for hyponatremia (water intoxication) following fear of medication toxicity.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking evaluation for tinnitus; hesitant about medical imaging due to anxiety about contrast dye.

history.present_illness: Patient reported sudden onset of right tinnitus on June 6, 2018. Prior to evaluation, she consumed a partial Mucinex pill, feared toxicity, and drank >70 bottles of water, leading to ICU admission for hyponatremia.
history.otologic_history: Sudden hearing loss in right ear.
history.medical_psych_history: History of anxiety. Recent ICU stay for hyponatremia.
history.prior_management: PA recommended steroids for sudden hearing loss and MRI (patient refused MRI).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Normal hearing through 4000 Hz, steeply sloping to moderate-to-severe loss at 6000-8000 Hz. Left ear: Normal hearing sensitivity 250-8000 Hz. Negative Stenger.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent word recognition bilaterally with no rollover.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Absent left contralateral reflexes. Present right contralateral and bilateral ipsilateral reflexes.

history.present_illness: Follow-up for tinnitus evaluation approx 2 months after initial ENT visit.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Ultra-high frequency audiometry. Right ear loss continues through 16 kHz, recovering to normal at 18-20 kHz. Left ear normal 10-20 kHz except mild dip at 16 kHz.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a right unilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss (steeply sloping >4 kHz) and normal hearing in the left ear. Ultra-high frequency testing confirms the loss extends to 16 kHz in the right ear before recovering. Acoustic reflexes are abnormal (absent left contralateral). Tinnitus is matched to a low frequency (1000 Hz) despite the high-frequency loss configuration.
counseling_points: We recommend sound therapy using a 'mixing point' strategy: set the sound level just below where it completely covers your tinnitus to help your brain habituate.
Because your hearing loss and reflexes are asymmetric (different between ears), an ABR test or MRI is strongly recommended to rule out retrocochlear pathology, despite your concerns about contrast.
We recommend psychiatric counseling to help manage the anxiety you are experiencing, which can exacerbate tinnitus perception.
Sound therapy apps on your smartphone can be a cost-effective way to manage the tinnitus.
notes_for_actor: Portray high anxiety, specifically regarding medication and medical procedures (MRI contrast).
You are fixated on the 'Mucinex incident' and the subsequent hospitalization.
You are hesitant to undergo the MRI but are bothered by the tinnitus.
